text.headline: Ben Franklin knew the score!
text.text:
Writeup: Dr Benjamin Franklin is seemingly predicting airborne viruses responsible for influenza and others associated with the common cold, and drawing a connection to becoming clinically ill with poor dietary choices (2017 writeup; see also Benjamin Franklin Would Get Social Distancing).

He also said in 1785 'I am persuaded that no common Air from without, is so unwholesome as the Air within a close Room, that has been often breath'd and not changed.'.

Find this book here

text.headline: Fresh air known to be important for army medical camps
text.text:
As long ago as 1753, Pringle, a doctor, studied medical army camp hospitals. He found that fresh air was important to stop disease spread.

post (@jmcrookston).

Also this (@jmcrookston)

text.headline: Fresh air again referred to as important
text.text:
Fodere, in his treatise Lecons sur les epidemies, noted that fresh air in hospitals was important. Part of the text in this picture reads 'Make hospitals well isolated, well aired, with many air currents produced by ventilators and don't fill it with a large number of ill patients ...'

post here (@jmcrookston)

media.caption: Charles Chapin - Methods for the prevention of scarlet fever (1888)

text.headline: Charles Chapin knew scarlet fever was occasionally airborne
text.text:
Charles Chapin, who would later promote that most transmission was droplet borne, appreciated that scarlet fever could occasionally infect someone on the second floor of a house from the first - it was therefore airborne.

His book.
